Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 912, 91]]<|/det|>
1 The random variables \(X\) and \(Y\) have the independent distributions \(\mathrm{N}(44,16)\) and \(\mathrm{N}(30,9)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 282, 122]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X-Y<15)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 785, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A researcher records the time, \(T\) seconds, taken by adults to complete a questionnaire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
The results for a random sample of 60 adults who completed the questionnaire this year are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 147, 700, 168]]<|/det|>
\[
n=60 \quad \sum t=3678 \quad \sum t^{2}=226313.36
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 183, 144, 200]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 858, 200]]<|/det|>
(a) Find an unbiased estimate of \(\operatorname{E}(T)\), and show that an unbiased estimate of \(\operatorname{Var}(T)\) is 14.44 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 554, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>In the past, the population mean time was 62.4 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
(b) Test at the \(2 \%\) significance level whether the population mean time for this year is less than 62.4 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 675, 144, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 675, 918, 708]]<|/det|>
(c) State, with a reason, whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit Theorem in your answer to part (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 522, 91]]<|/det|>
3 The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(1.5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 104, 280, 122]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\mathrm{P}(X \geqslant 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 476, 144, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 473, 918, 491]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that the sum of three independent values of \(X\) is between 3 and 5 inclusive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) The sum of a large number, \(n\), of values of \(X\) is denoted by \(T\). Using a suitable approximation, it was found that \(\mathrm{P}(T>330)=0.0391\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 312, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 71, 124, 89]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 74, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 71, 124, 89]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 98, 715, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 276, 918, 325]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of the probability density function, f , of a random variable \(X\). The graph is a straight line from (0, \(a)\) to (2, \(b)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants. Elsewhere, \(\mathrm{f}(x)=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 339, 180, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 339, 359, 356]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that \(b=1-a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 188, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 494, 534, 511]]<|/det|>
(ii) Given that \(\mathrm{E}(X)=1.2\), find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 643, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) A random variable \(T\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[352, 103, 645, 151]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{g}(t)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{2} \cos t & -\frac{1}{2} \pi \leqslant t \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \pi, \\ 0 & \text { otherwise. }\end{cases}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 163, 542, 185]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(c\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(-c<t<c)=\frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
5 Amir believes that \(20 \%\) of the students at his college are left-handed. His friend believes that the true proportion, \(p\), is less than \(20 \%\). Amir plans to use the binomial distribution to test the null hypothesis, \(\mathrm{H}_{0}: p=0.2\), against the alternative hypothesis, \(\mathrm{H}_{1}: p<0.2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
He decides to choose 35 students at random. If 3 or fewer of these students are left-handed, Amir will reject his belief.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 183, 144, 200]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 452, 199]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the significance level of the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 739, 144, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 738, 452, 755]]<|/det|>
(b) State the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 477, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is now given that the true value of \(p\) is 0.05 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 106, 455, 122]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
6 Nikki is investigating the views of students at her school about the school sports facilities. She plans to give a survey to a sample of students.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
Nikki's friend says, "This survey is about sports facilities, so you should choose a sample of students from the school sports teams."

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 167, 144, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 166, 621, 184]]<|/det|>
(a) State, with a reason, whether you agree with Nikki's friend.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 918, 323]]<|/det|>
<pre>Nikki chooses an appropriate random sample of 60 students. She finds that 45 of these students think that the sports facilities are good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 338, 144, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 336, 918, 370]]<|/det|>
(b) Calculate an approximate \(95 \%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students who think that the sports facilities are good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
<pre>For a different investigation, Nikki uses another large random sample to calculate a \(99 \%\) confidence interval and an \(x \%\) confidence interval.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 834, 139]]<|/det|>
<pre>The width of the \(99 \%\) confidence interval is double the width of the \(x \%\) confidence interval.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 153, 144, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 152, 349, 170]]<|/det|>
(c) Calculate the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
